Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2008 07:53AM - edited Dec 18, 2008 08:06PM by kelly1215 I have been on Taxotere for the past 2.5 years (with one 4 month break), which adds up to 40 treatments so far. I get a higher dose every three weeks. It is hard at times, but tolerable. Side effects I have experienced are: fatique, hair loss, fingernails and toenails messed up, drippy nose and watery eyes, weight gain, and just that yucky chemofied feeling. No nausea or stomach stuff. The worst of my side effects hit 3-5 days after treatment. I have 2-3 really bad days where I mostly just sleep. I've scheduled my treatments for Wednesday so that those bad days will hit over the weekend. It sounds like you have a good man by your side...that counts for a lot in this crazy battle of ours. Hang in there...Taxotere IS doable!
Posts.Title: Taxotere, word of the day LynnW Reneepals

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2009 01:46PM - edited Jan 19, 2009 01:47PM by kelly1215 LOL Denise!  I have been drawing my eyebrows on for almost 3 years now. It is hilarious when one gets rubbed off, or when I draw them on differently. It looks like I am all mixed up...one side of me is mad, the other is surprised; one side is happy, the other is skeptical...I can rarely get them on evenly. I ordered some temporary tattoo eyebrows last year (also from headcovers.com, I think), they looked pretty good but they eventually got rubbed off too. I bought some fake eyelashes, but they looked stupid when I tried to put them on. I think it helps to already have a base of eyelashes to add the falsies to, not just bare eyelid skin.
Posts.Title: Eyebrows denise1962 JoyRebecca

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2009 06:10AM kelly1215 wrote: Hi Kara, You've come to a great place for support and advice. The women here are amazing. Hopefully you won't need it, but If you're looking for a site that is specifically for young women, Young Survival Coalition is a great place for those of us who were diagnosed in our 20's and 30's. Unfortunately, it's becoming more common for women to be diagnosed at younger ages and some of our issues are different than our older BC sisters (i.e. fertility). Good luck with your tests on Friday! Hugs, Kelly

Posts.Content: Dec 9, 2008 11:32PM - edited Dec 10, 2008 10:12PM by kelly1215 Hi PineHouse, Joanie, Kim & Amy, I am still leaning toward Doxil. I meet with my onc. next Tuesday to discuss our plan of attack. I won't have my first treatment until the week of 12/29. I have that week off of work, so I thought that would be a good time to try out a new drug and learn its side effects/timing of the crap. I was really hoping to be able to get away from the Decadron since I have such a love/hate relationship with it.  Sounds like there will be several of us on Doxil...that's good, we can help each other through. Thank you all so much for your input! Hugs, Kelly p.s. - Kim...I am originally from Jax and still have family who live there (Orange Park).
Posts.Title: Are you (Doxil) Experienced? kelly1215 Bmarie

Posts.Content: Dec 10, 2008 11:22PM kelly1215 wrote: Joanie, Sounds like we were in Jax around the same timeframe. I born in Sanford in December '64, and we moved to Jax while I was still a baby in '65.  I went to St. Andrew's in Arlington K-2, and then Englewood Elementary in Southside for 3rd & 4th grade. My Mom, sister, and brother were all born in St. Vincent's. My grandparents lived in Riverside We moved to southern Missouri (where my Dad's family lives) in '74, then to KC in '83. Crazy that there are three of us in this Stage 4/Doxil thread that have a Jax connection. Maybe there's something in the water!  ~Kelly
Posts.Title: Are you (Doxil) Experienced? kelly1215 Bmarie

Posts.Content: Dec 10, 2008 11:33PM kelly1215 wrote: Kim, I have never had Neulasta, so I can't speak from experience, but I have heard that it does cause aches and pains. Sometimes it's hard to determine what's causing what when there's so many drugs in us. Michigan is cold, I have a friend who lives in Grand Rapids. KC is cold enough for me. I miss the warmth of FL, and of course the ocean. Until I got sick, I've gone back to FL once a year. We would fly into Jax and then drive down to St. Augustine. Love it there. I miss that. Just one more thing cancer's taken. I'd love to get back to the ocean someday though... ~Kelly
Posts.Title: Are you (Doxil) Experienced? kelly1215 Bmarie

Posts.Content: kelly1215 wrote: Can anyone share their experience with Doxil? Side effects, down time (and when it hits), just the usual chemo stuff to expect. I have been on Taxotere for two years, but according to my onc., my rising TM's, and a growing lesion on my liver, it's time to switch drugs. He threw out several options, but didn't really tell me which would be best...Xeloda, Navelbine, Doxil, and Gemzar. I think I am leaning toward Doxil, but wanted to get the real scoop from real people who have real life experience with it. Posts.Content: Mar 19, 2008 11:44PM kelly1215 wrote: when i was diagnosed with mets i remember wanting to just run away, but then automatically thinking that no matter where i went my problems would go with me because my own stupid f-ed up body would be with me. i can't get away from ME. i try to stay away from extra pharmacueticals when/if i can just because of extra side effects and fact that they all pretty much just knock me out, which isn't good during the day/at work. i do take benedryl at night sometimes, and it seems to help me sleep. a friend gave me xanax today. i haven't taken it yet (and now it's too late...1:35am...steroids, agh!). supposedly it's good stuff, i might need to get my doc to write me a scrip for some. oh, and yesterday my doc gave me prescriptions for: 1) ritalin - for energy, and 2) viagra - for libido (ha!). i haven't filled them yet though. they're stuck away with my unfilled scrip for hydrocodone. a druggie would love to find my stash of unfilled scrips! i say do whatever helps you get thru. i've been doing ct scans every third cycle, and bone scans every sixth. the first few are the worst/scariest, then it just becomes part of your routine. hang in there, girl! hugs & love, ~k
Posts.Title: 3 months sounds like forever.... AlaskaDeb lisaAB

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2008 09:43AM kelly1215 wrote: i wrote to you on your site this morning, which is when i found out about your stupid new diagnosis. yeah, i said it...stupid. this SUCKS. as you know, i am a year and a half and 31 treatments into stage 4ville. i don't have any coping skills to share...for me it's just day by day, hour by hour, minute by minute, second by second. one foot in front of the other, do what i have to do to get thru. i still can't grasp the 'indefinite/forever' concept. my tiny brain just can't fathom it. you have helped me thru. i am here. you know where. ask me anything. i know your world is in upheaval, i know you'll be having a lot of tests/appointments. once you have a game plan in place, you can get in 'take care of business/attack' mode. where you're at now is one of the scariest places to be. sorry for my inability to articulate anything that makes sense. i am still in shock, and so so angry at this f-ing disease. lean on us. we're here for you, just like you have been here for so many of us. sending love and strength and big hugs your way, ~k
Posts.Title: How do I cope with mets...anyone want to teach the 101 class?? AlaskaDeb slonedeb

Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2009 08:02AM - edited Feb 10, 2009 02:35PM by kelly1215 Even with bad scans, rising tumor markers, more and more symptoms from the cancer and years of chemo, I am still happy to be here, happy to be alive even if it's only a temporary thing (isn't all of life (on earth) just temporary?). Our sister angels would want us to be happy, to enjoy life, to celebrate their lives and the fact that we are still here with our friends and families. That's what I would want anyway, when it is my time to join them. Sandy: I love that video!

Posts.Content: Dec 11, 2008 11:51AM kelly1215 wrote: No Zometa here. It isn't extremely painful, but it does hurt when it happens.  I have told my doc, but he doesn't seem to think it's any big deal. He gave me the scrip for Gabapentin and that's it.  I guess I'm weird (no surprise there). I'm sure it's some kind of SE from something (chemo, clot, Coumadin, cancer), just wondered if anyone else had experienced it too. It seems to have passed for now, I could eat solid food today w/o any jaw lockage. Thanks for your responses!

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2009 04:00PM - edited Feb 16, 2009 12:22PM by kelly1215 My Grateful List: 1. I am alive and feeling pretty good. 2. The sun is shining and it is 73 in KC today!!!! 3. I got to spend time with two different sets of girlfriends this past weekend. 4. The weather was nice then too, so we had lunch (and two pitchers of margaritas) at the Plaza...and we sat outside! 5. I got my state and federal tax refunds last week . 6. It's supposed to rain tonight. 7. I had sex this past weekend too...and enjoyed it! 8. I went to my niece's 12th birthday party and got to see my family. 9. I still walk, drive, and go to the bathroom by myself. 10. I can still work full-time.

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2009 10:47AM - edited Feb 18, 2009 12:32PM by kelly1215 35 (stage 2b...found lump on my own, was sent for first mammo) - 2000 41 (mets...again found on my own & took me months to convince docs) - 2006 My sister was 31 and pregnant when I was first diagnosed. After she had the baby and stopped breastfeeding, she had her first mammogram and has had one every year since. She turned 40 last October. Her mammo's are covered by her insurance because of the age at which I was diagnosed.
Posts.Title: Poll - How old were you when dx with BC Times3 Minetta57

Posts.Content: kelly1215 wrote: Has anyone else had issues with their jaw locking up? It seems to be at its worst 4-5 days after chemo (Taxotere). I had 36 treatments without this happening, then I developed a blood clot (caused by port) and am now on Coumadin. I have had 4 more treatments since the clot and each time I've had this problem so I am wondering if that might be the cause. My doc has no answers other than giving me more drugs...Gabapentin (sp), which I believe is a muscle relaxer. I haven't taken any yet since it always seems to pass in a few days but this time I haven't been able to eat solid food for two days because every time I try to chew my jaw locks up. I am so hungry! In addition, the muscles in my neck seize up when I yawn or move a certain way...it's pretty painful. It seems to extend down into my kidney (back/side) area. I'm a MESS...2.5 years of chemo really does a number on your body. Dx 5/23/2006, Stage IV, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Jaw Locking kelly1215 Fightcancer247

Posts.Content: Dec 5, 2008 06:06PM kelly1215 wrote: Yes, I did have that tingling sensation in my upper back prior to being diagnosed with mets. I still have it at times. Not sure if it has anything to do with cancer. I thought it might be residual stuff leftvoer from radiation. The docs never seem to have answers for these kinds of symptoms since they can be caused by many different things. Good luck & hugs to you!
Posts.Title: Tingling spot in back evieo mye

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2009 10:57PM kelly1215 wrote: It not only depends on one's diagnosis, it also depends on one's age and health in general. There are times when chemo and/or surgery are not recommended if they feel they would only do more harm than good. There are always doctors who will agree to do either or both if you choose to find them. Get a second or third opinion if after asking more questions you truly feel like your mom's current doctor doesn't want to waste time on her. She needs to do whatever she is comfortable with. Best of luck to you and your Mom!

Posts.Title: Man on Moon, Obama President, Cure for Cancer TripleNeg Mamie2

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2009 10:35AM - edited Jan 31, 2009 10:36AM by kelly1215 I was recently diagnosed with 'true vocal cord paralysis' after my voice became raspy and weak. I cannot pronounce certain words and especially the letter 'e'. An ENT put a scope thingy up my nose that went down my throat and then he had me say certain things so he could see the vocal cords at work. I have mets to the mediastinal area, pleural effusion, pericardial effusion, and a blood clot in the super vena cava. They say all of this is causing the vocal cord paralysis. I just had PET and head/neck CT yesterday. Isn't it frustrating not being able to speak properly? I get so upset when people can't hear or understand me. And I can't yell at my boyfriend! He made the mistake of making fun of my voice yesterday. Tears always make men feel bad, but these tears were real and I was so pissed that he would be so heartless. Anyway, I am sorry you're going through this and I hope you get some answers (and solutions) soon! Hugs, Kelly
Posts.Title: Voice Box (Larynx) Nodule NYCarol riverinerabbit
